newsitem.title: USA: Oracle sees 1,000 NCs in Japan this spring.
newsitem.headline: Oracle sees 1,000 NCs in Japan this spring.

text.p: Oracle Corp. Chief Executive Officer Larry Ellison said Tuesday he expected a large installation of the much-touted network computer, or NC, this spring, with about 1,000 of the machines to be delivered in Japan in April.

Ellison, whose company is the leading database management software company, said 1,000 network computers and 100 servers -- the computers that run computer networks -- will be delivered during Oracle's Open World conference in Japan in mid-April.
A spokeswoman declined to comment further on Ellison's brief comments, which came during a conference call to announce a licensing agreement with Borland International Inc.
Oracle is one of the big proponents of stripped-down, lower-cost network computers vs. more expensive and more powerful personal computers.

Oracle declined to say which company will produce the network computers in Japan. Oracle is developing software to run on the network computers, which are also being developed by Sun Microsystems Inc. and International Business Machines Corp.

Network computers are computers with limited memory and no peripherals such as disk drives or CD-ROMs. The software, which runs on the network computers, resides on a server. Network computers have been likened to dumb terminals accessing mainframe computers.
Oracle, Sun, IBM and others have defined a set of specifications for the development of network computers, and several Japanese companies are developing NCs.
